articles.title: Mapping the Amygdala Leads to New Hope For Cocaine Addiction - Neuroscience News
articles.description: Researchers crafted a detailed atlas of the amygdala, revealing new insights into emotional responses and potential treatments for cocaine addiction.
articles.content:

articles.title: Viral kinetics of sequential SARS-CoV-2 infections - Nature.com
articles.description: In this study, the authors compare the viral kinetics of first and second SARS-CoV-2 infections using data from an occupational surveillance scheme in the National Basketball League. They find that second infections tend to have a faster clearance time, and t…

articles.author: Ashley Rindsberg
articles.title: The Lancet was made for political activism - UnHerd
articles.description: For 200 years, it has thrived on melodrama and scandal
articles.content: In the rarefied world of scientific publishing, few names strike quite the same chord as The Lancet. Across the globe, the journal is associated with scientific rigour and professional prestige. In t… [+14908 chars]

articles.title: Sialoglycan binding triggers spike opening in a human coronavirus - Nature.com
articles.description: Binding of a sialoglycan-based primary receptor by the spike protein of the common cold human coronavirus HKU1 triggers conformational changes to a state that would allow binding to a second receptor required for cell entry.

articles.author: Marisa Wexler, MS
articles.title: MS patients in UK less likely to be on treatment, new study shows... - Multiple Sclerosis News Today
articles.description: Compared with MS patients in other countries in Europe, those in the U.K. are less likely to be on disease-modifying treatment, a study shows.
articles.content:
People with multiple sclerosis (MS) in the United Kingdom are less likely to be on disease-modifying treatments (DMTs) compared with MS patients in other countries in Europe, a new study reports.
